com.itko.lisa.editor

Interface Controller

  • All Superinterfaces:
    com.itko.lisa.gui.ContextHelpSupport, com.itko.lisa.model.IWriteXML
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ControllerBase, TestNodeInfo

    public interface Controller
extends com.itko.lisa.model.IWriteXML, com.itko.lisa.gui.ContextHelpSupport
    Within the LISA Test Manager, every editable object has a Controller. This forms the basic contract that every object must provide, although many are not always needed. Customers should not worry as much about this interface as the classes that implement it. You will likely not need to implement from here, but one of the base classes that already exist.

      • Methods inherited from interface com.itko.lisa.gui.ContextHelpSupport

        getHelpString

    • Method Detail

      • getIntersections

        com.itko.lisa.editor.Intersections getIntersections()
        LISA has a dynamic way to hook test case elements with their Controller and Editors. This method is used so that this can be done.
        Returns:
        an Intersections object

      • getControllerFactory

        com.itko.lisa.editor.ControllerFactory getControllerFactory()
        This is the factory for controllers of this type.
        Returns:
        the controller factory so we can make these controllers

      • setEditorTarget

        void setEditorTarget(TestCaseInfo tc,
                   TestNodeInfo node)
        Called on this object by the framework to let you know what test case you are scoped into and the test node. Node can be null if we aren't a node-level editor...

      • getTestNode

        TestNodeInfo getTestNode()
        So that your subclasses and editors know the node you are related to
        Returns:
        the node or null if n/a

      • migrate

        void migrate(java.lang.Object testCaseObj)
        If the test case object that you are going to maintain already existed in an existing test, then we need you to migrate the state of that exsiting element into your state here. Often, this is no more than just keeping a reference to the test case element object. At your discresion, you might do anything else you wish.
        Parameters:
        testCaseObj - the object to migrate (like the TestNode, FilterInterface, etc.)

      • setType

        void setType(java.lang.String type)
        When initially constructed for a new test element (no migration), the framework will call this to tell you what type of object you own. This is a FQCN
        Parameters:
        type - the class name of the element we are making for you to edit, like "com.itko.lisa.test.URLTrans"

      • writeXML

        void writeXML(java.io.PrintWriter pw)
        When it's time for you to stream your XML representation to the output stream. Output just your own attributes. Consider parent class attributes already written.
        Specified by:
        writeXML in interface com.itko.lisa.model.IWriteXML
        Parameters:
        pw - the output writer to push your data into

      • getEditorName

        java.lang.String getEditorName()
        Tell us the title of the window to use when creating dialogs and etc.

      • getDisplayName

        java.lang.String getDisplayName()
        Fashion for us a short name for use in trees and lists

      • isRenamingAllowed

        boolean isRenamingAllowed()
        Can be renamed? Tell us if you can rename this element

      • getElementName

        java.lang.String getElementName()
        If renaming is allowed, then the framework might call this method to fetch the name. This is different from the EditorName b/c it's the name given to this element by the user

      • renameElement

        void renameElement(java.lang.String newName)
        Here is how you can rename the element from the framework level

      • makeEditor

        CustomEditor makeEditor()
        You are responsible for telling us what UI editor to use, so please give it here. You should probably just make one of these and cache it for all similar uses. The framework no longer calls this, just goes straight to showEditor, but you will likely still want one of these...
        Returns:
        the editor that will show and edit this controller's data

      • showEditor

        CustomEditor showEditor()
        When the framework needs to actually put the editor on screen, you'll get called here. This is called every time so you have the opportunity to sync the editor with the current version of your data.
        Returns:
        the editor

      • isEditorCompact

        boolean isEditorCompact()
        The framework uses this method to determine whether the editor for this controller is designed to fit in the narrow inspector (true) or if it requires more real estate (false).
        Returns:
        true if the controller's editor will fit in the model editor object inspector or false if not.

      • hasChanged

        boolean hasChanged()
        The framework is asking if you or your editor have changed the data inside (typically called when the user is moving focus away from your editor)
        Returns:
        true if so

      • isEditorValid

        java.lang.String isEditorValid()
        We expect you to inspect the editor and your internal data if appropriate, and return a human readable string of an error that should be addressed, or null if there is no problem.
        Returns:
        string of the error to display or null if no problem

      • save

        void save()
        We are asking you to persist from your editor into your state, this is usually called after the user is done if your editor, and we have called hasChanged() and isEditorValid() w/o issues.

      • isInInvalidState

        boolean isInInvalidState()
        This is basically just a boolean version of isEditorValid
        Returns:
        true if the editor shown has problems

      • confirmDelete

        boolean confirmDelete()
        You can question/challenge/prevent deletes
        Returns:
        true if it's OK to delete

      • objectDeleted

        void objectDeleted()
        This method is called when the user has deleted this controller (and the object it represents) from the containing model.

      • destroy

        void destroy()
        When we're shutting down the whole thing, we'll want to clean up model and viewer This is your chance to make sure you aren't doing anything to leak memory

      • gatherStepConnections

        void gatherStepConnections(java.util.Collection<com.itko.lisa.test.StepConnection> stepConnections)
        This method is used for gathering information used in graphing and realizing who's talking to whom. Note: this data gets stale fast, so the framework calls this often if the user is graphing or changing step names.
        Parameters:
        stepConnections - the collection to add all the step connections this editor knows about as StepConnection objects to.
        See Also:
        StepConnection

      • getPropertiesReferenced

        java.util.Collection getPropertiesReferenced()
        Will tell us all the properties that are referenced during the processing of this element
        Returns:
        a Collection of Strings of the properties

      • getPropertiesSet

        java.util.Collection getPropertiesSet()
        Will tell us all the properties that are set/updated during the processing of this element
        Returns:
        a Collection of Strings of the properties

      • getLastErrorMessage

        java.lang.String getLastErrorMessage()
        Used by the GUI to display a better message. We want you to cache the last time your isEditorValid() message was an error. This is not required but will give the user the error when the framework is confirming that the test is in a valid state.

      • exportAssets

        void exportAssets()
